statement.text: Chronic Mesenteric Ischemia (CMI), also known as intestinal angina, is a condition of inadequate postprandial intestinal blood flow caused by progressive atherosclerotic narrowing of the mesenteric arteries, classically presenting with postprandial abdominal pain, food fear, and significant weight loss.
statement.formal: CMI: Progressive mesenteric arterial stenosis → Inadequate postprandial blood flow augmentation → Relative ischemia → Postprandial pain → Food avoidance → Malnutrition

explanation.intuition: Just as angina pectoris represents inadequate coronary blood flow during increased cardiac demand, intestinal angina represents inadequate mesenteric blood flow during the increased demand of digestion. The intestine 'cramps' after eating because it cannot get enough blood to digest the meal.
explanation.key_insight: CMI is remarkably rare despite the high prevalence of mesenteric atherosclerosis because of extensive collateral networks between the celiac, SMA, and IMA. Typically, two of the three major vessels must be severely stenosed or occluded before symptoms develop. This same collateral network makes CMI amenable to single-vessel revascularization.
explanation.technical_details: The mesenteric circulation has robust collateral pathways: (1) pancreaticoduodenal arcades connecting celiac and SMA, (2) marginal artery of Drummond and arc of Riolan connecting SMA and IMA, (3) hemorrhoidal circulation connecting IMA to internal iliacs. These collaterals can maintain adequate baseline flow but fail to meet the 50-100% increase in blood flow required for digestion.

definitions_glossary.CMI: Chronic Mesenteric Ischemia - gradual inadequate intestinal blood flow
definitions_glossary.intestinal_angina: Classic CMI symptom of postprandial abdominal pain
definitions_glossary.food_fear: Sitophobia - avoidance of eating due to anticipated pain
definitions_glossary.marginal_artery_of_Drummond: Collateral arcade along the colon connecting SMA and IMA territories
definitions_glossary.arc_of_Riolan: Central collateral connecting the SMA and IMA via colic arteries
definitions_glossary.two_vessel_rule: Clinical observation that CMI typically requires ≥2 vessel disease

postprandial_pain.description: Dull, crampy periumbilical pain beginning 15-30 minutes after eating
postprandial_pain.pattern: Worse with larger meals, especially fatty foods

food_fear.description: Avoidance of eating to prevent pain

weight_loss.mechanism: Combination of food fear and malabsorption

red_flags: Acute worsening of symptoms - may indicate acute-on-chronic thrombosis

vessel_involvement_patterns.single_vessel: Rarely symptomatic unless IMA sacrificed during AAA repair
vessel_involvement_patterns.two_vessel: More commonly symptomatic, especially celiac + SMA

collateral_pathways.clinical_importance: Most important for SMA occlusion tolerance

collateral_pathways.description: Via middle colic → left colic → marginal artery
collateral_pathways.clinical_importance: Critical when sacrificing IMA during AAA repair

anatomic_considerations.lesion_location: Typically ostial or proximal (first 2 cm) due to aortic atherosclerosis

differential_diagnosis.distinguishing_features: Eating often relieves pain; no weight loss
Different pain pattern; history of alcohol or gallstones
Must be excluded; imaging helps differentiate
Younger patients; compression at celiac origin

diagnosis.clinical_suspicion: Essential - must consider CMI in unexplained weight loss with postprandial pain

angiography.role: Gold standard, now mainly for intervention

natural_history.acute_conversion: 5-20% risk of progression to AMI (acute-on-chronic thrombosis)
natural_history.mortality_untreated: Progressive malnutrition and eventual bowel infarction

related.relationship: CMI patients often have concurrent PAD and CAD

sources.citation: Hohenwalter EJ. Chronic mesenteric ischemia: diagnosis and treatment. Semin Intervent Radiol. 2009

learning_objectives: Define CMI and understand the two-vessel rule
Understand the role of collateral circulation
clinical_pearls: The 'two-vessel rule' explains why CMI is rare despite common mesenteric atherosclerosis
Weight loss is typically severe (>10 kg) - mild weight loss suggests alternative diagnosis
Postprandial pain pattern (15-30 min after eating, lasts 1-3 hrs) is key
Beware acute-on-chronic: sudden worsening may herald impending acute thrombosis
